统计场论第六章

6 Lattice systems

6.1 Models and methods

While Wilson's perturbative RG provides a systematic approach to probing critical properties, carrying out the ϵ\epsilonϵ-expansion to high orders is quite cumbersome. Models defined on a discrete lattice provide a number of alternative computational routes that can complement the perturbative RG approach. Because of universality, we expect that all models with appropriate microscopic symmetries and range of interactions, no matter how simplified, lead to the same critical exponents. Lattice models are convenient for visualization, computer simulation, and series expansion purposes. We shall thus describe models in which an appropriate "spin" degree of freedom is placed on each site of a lattice, and the spins are subject to simple interaction energies. While such models are formulated in terms of explicit "microscopic" degrees of freedom, depending on their degree of complexity, they may or may not provide a more accurate description of a specific material than the Landau-Ginzburg model. The point is that universality dictates that both descriptions describe the same macroscopic physics, and the choice of continuum or discrete models is then a matter of computational convenience.

Fig. 6.1 Interacting "spins" {si}\left\{s_{i}\right\}{si​} defined on a square lattice.

Some commonly used lattice models are described here: (1) The Ising model is the simplest and most widely applied paradigm in statistical mechanics. At each site iii of a lattice, there is a spin σi\sigma_{i}σi​ which takes the two values of +1 or -1 . Each state may correspond to one of two species in a binary mixture, or to empty and occupied cells in a lattice approximation to an interacting gas. The simplest possible short-range interaction involves only neighboring spins, and is described by a Hamiltonian

H=∑⟨i,j⟩B^(σi,σj),\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=\sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \widehat{B}\left(\sigma_{i}, \sigma_{j}\right), \tag{6.1} \end{equation*}H=⟨i,j⟩∑​B(σi​,σj​),​(6.1)​

where the notation ⟨i,j⟩\langle i, j\rangle⟨i,j⟩ is commonly used to indicate the sum over all nearest neighbor pairs on the lattice. Since σi2=1\sigma_{i}^{2}=1σi2​=1, the most general interaction between two spins is

B^(σ,σ′)=−g^−h^z(σ+σ′)−Jσσ′\begin{equation*} \widehat{B}\left(\sigma, \sigma^{\prime}\right)=-\widehat{g}-\frac{\widehat{h}}{z}\left(\sigma+\sigma^{\prime}\right)-J \sigma \sigma^{\prime} \tag{6.2} \end{equation*}B(σ,σ′)=−g​−zh​(σ+σ′)−Jσσ′​(6.2)​

For NNN spins, there are 2N2^{N}2N possible microstates, and the (Gibbs) partition function is

Z=∑{σi}e−βH=∑{σi}exp⁡[K∑⟨i,j⟩σiσj+h∑iσi+g]\begin{equation*} Z=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}}=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \exp \left[K \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}+h \sum_{i} \sigma_{i}+g\right] \tag{6.3} \end{equation*}Z={σi​}∑​e−βH={σi​}∑​exp​K⟨i,j⟩∑​σi​σj​+hi∑​σi​+g​​(6.3)​

where we have set K=βJ,h=βh^K=\beta J, h=\beta \widehat{h}K=βJ,h=βh, and g=zβg^/2(β=1/kBTg=z \beta \widehat{g} / 2\left(\beta=1 / k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right.g=zβg​/2(β=1/kB​T, and zzz is the number of bonds per site, i.e. the coordination number of the lattice). For h=0h=0h=0 at T=0T=0T=0, the ground state has a two fold degeneracy with all spins pointing up or down (K>0)(K>0)(K>0). This order is destroyed at a critical Kc=J/kBTcK_{c}=J / k_{\mathrm{B}} T_{c}Kc​=J/kB​Tc​ with a phase transition to a disordered state. The field hhh breaks the up−u p-up− down symmetry and removes the phase transition. The parameter ggg merely shifts the origin of energy, and has no effect on the relative weights of microstates, or the macroscopic properties.

All the following models can be regarded as generalizations of the Ising model. (2) The O(n)\boldsymbol{O}(\boldsymbol{n})O(n) model: Each lattice site is now occupied by an nnn-component unit vector, i.e

Si≡(Si1,Si2,⋯ ,Sin), with ∑α=1n(Siα)2=1\begin{equation*} S_{i} \equiv\left(S_{i}^{1}, S_{i}^{2}, \cdots, S_{i}^{n}\right), \quad \text { with } \quad \sum_{\alpha=1}^{n}\left(S_{i}^{\alpha}\right)^{2}=1 \tag{6.4} \end{equation*}Si​≡(Si1​,Si2​,⋯,Sin​), with α=1∑n​(Siα​)2=1​(6.4)​

A nearest-neighbor interaction can be written as

H=−J∑⟨i,j⟩S⃗i⋅S⃗j−h⃗^⋅∑iS⃗i\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=-J \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \vec{S}_{i} \cdot \vec{S}_{j}-\widehat{\vec{h}} \cdot \sum_{i} \vec{S}_{i} \tag{6.5} \end{equation*}H=−J⟨i,j⟩∑​Si​⋅Sj​−h⋅i∑​Si​​(6.5)​

In fact, the most general interaction consistent with spherical symmetry is f(S⃗i⋅S⃗j)f\left(\vec{S}_{i} \cdot \vec{S}_{j}\right)f(Si​⋅Sj​) for an arbitrary function fff. Similarly, the rotational symmetry can be broken by a number of "fields" such as ∑i(h⃗p⋅S⃗i)p\sum_{i}\left(\vec{h}_{p} \cdot \vec{S}_{i}\right)^{p}∑i​(hp​⋅Si​)p. Specific cases are the Ising model (n=1)(n=1)(n=1), the XY model (n=2)(n=2)(n=2), and the Heisenberg model (n=3)(n=3)(n=3). (3) The Potts model: Each site of the lattice is occupied by a qqq-valued spin Si≡S_{i} \equivSi​≡ 1,2,⋯ ,q1,2, \cdots, q1,2,⋯,q. The interactions between the spins are described by the Hamiltonian

H=−J∑⟨i,j⟩δSi,Sj−h^∑iδSi,1\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=-J \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \delta_{S_{i}, S_{j}}-\widehat{h} \sum_{i} \delta_{S_{i}, 1} \tag{6.6} \end{equation*}H=−J⟨i,j⟩∑​δSi​,Sj​​−hi∑​δSi​,1​​(6.6)​

The field hhh now breaks the permutation symmetry amongst the qqq-states. The Ising model is recovered for q=2q=2q=2, since δσ,σ′=(1+σσ′)/2\delta_{\sigma, \sigma^{\prime}}=\left(1+\sigma \sigma^{\prime}\right) / 2δσ,σ′​=(1+σσ′)/2. The three state Potts

Fig. 6.2 A configuration of Ising spins on a square lattice. model can for example describe the distortion of a cube along one of its faces. Potts models with q>2q>2q>2 represent new universality classes not covered by the O(n)O(n)O(n) model. Actually, the transitions for q≥4q \geq 4q≥4 in d=2d=2d=2, and q>3q>3q>3 in d=3d=3d=3 are discontinuous. (4) Spin s-models: The spin at each site takes the 2s+12 s+12s+1 values, si=−s,−s+s_{i}=-s,-s+si​=−s,−s+ 1,⋯ ,+s1, \cdots,+s1,⋯,+s. A general nearest-neighbor Hamiltonian is

H=∑⟨i,j⟩(J1sisj+J2(sisj)2+⋯+J2s(sisj)2s)−h^∑isi.\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=\sum_{\langle i, j\rangle}\left(J_{1} s_{i} s_{j}+J_{2}\left(s_{i} s_{j}\right)^{2}+\cdots+J_{2 s}\left(s_{i} s_{j}\right)^{2 s}\right)-\widehat{h} \sum_{i} s_{i} . \tag{6.7} \end{equation*}H=⟨i,j⟩∑​(J1​si​sj​+J2​(si​sj​)2+⋯+J2s​(si​sj​)2s)−hi∑​si​.​(6.7)​

The Ising model corresponds to s=1/2s=1 / 2s=1/2, while s=1s=1s=1 is known as the Blume-EmeryGriffith (BEG) model. It describes a mixture of non-magnetic (s=0)(s=0)(s=0) and magnetic (s=±1(s= \pm 1(s=±1 ) elements. This model exhibits a tricritical point separating continuous and discontinuous transitions. However, since the ordered phase breaks an up-down symmetry, the phase transition belongs to the Ising universality class for all values of sss.

Some of the computational tools employed in the study of discrete models are: (1) Exact solutions can be obtained for a very limited subset of lattice models. These include many one dimensional systems that can be solved by the transfer matrix method described next, and the two-dimensional Ising model discussed in the next chapter. (2) Position space renormalizations: These are implementations of Kadanoff's RG scheme on lattice models. Some approximation is usually necessary to keep the space of interactions tractable. Most such approximations are uncontrolled; a number of them will be discussed in this chapter. (3) Monte Carlo simulations: The aim of such methods is to generate configurations of spins that are distributed with the correct Boltzmann weight exp⁡(−βH)\exp (-\beta \mathcal{H})exp(−βH). There are a number of methods, most notably the Metropolis algorithm, for achieving this aim. Various expectation values and correlation functions are then directly computed from these configurations. With the continuing increase of computer power, numerical simulations have become increasingly popular. Limitations of the method are due to the size of systems that can be studied, and the amount of time needed to ensure that the correctly weighted configurations are generated. There is an extensive literature on numerical simulations which will only be touched upon briefly. (4) Series expansions: Low-temperature expansions start with the ordered ground state and examine the lowest energy excitations around it (see the next chapter). High temperature expansions begin with the collection of non-interacting spins at infinite temperature and include the interactions between spins perturbatively. Critical behavior is then extracted from the singularities of such series.

6.2 Transfer matrices

Consider a linear chain of NNN Ising spins (σi=±1)\left(\sigma_{i}= \pm 1\right)(σi​=±1), with a nearest-neighbor coupling KKK, and a magnetic field hhh. To simplify calculations, we assume that the chain is closed upon itself such that the first and last spins are also coupled (periodic boundary conditions), resulting in the Hamiltonian

−βH=K(σ1σ2+σ2σ3+⋯+σN−1σN+σNσ1)+h∑i=1Nσi.\begin{equation*} -\beta \mathcal{H}=K\left(\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}+\sigma_{2} \sigma_{3}+\cdots+\sigma_{N-1} \sigma_{N}+\sigma_{N} \sigma_{1}\right)+h \sum_{i=1}^{N} \sigma_{i} . \tag{6.8} \end{equation*}−βH=K(σ1​σ2​+σ2​σ3​+⋯+σN−1​σN​+σN​σ1​)+hi=1∑N​σi​.​(6.8)​

The corresponding partition function, obtained by summing over all states, can be expressed as the product of matrices, since

Z=∑σ1=±1∑σ2=±1⋯∑σN=±1∏i=1Nexp⁡[Kσiσi+1+h2(σi+σi+1)]≡tr⁡[⟨σ1∣T∣σ2⟩⟨σ2∣T∣σ3⟩⋯⟨σN∣T∣σ1⟩]=tr⁡[TN]\begin{align*} Z & =\sum_{\sigma_{1}= \pm 1} \sum_{\sigma_{2}= \pm 1} \cdots \sum_{\sigma_{N}= \pm 1} \prod_{i=1}^{N} \exp \left[K \sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+1}+\frac{h}{2}\left(\sigma_{i}+\sigma_{i+1}\right)\right] \tag{6.9}\\ & \equiv \operatorname{tr}\left[\left\langle\sigma_{1}\right| T\left|\sigma_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle\sigma_{2}\right| T\left|\sigma_{3}\right\rangle \cdots\left\langle\sigma_{N}\right| T\left|\sigma_{1}\right\rangle\right]=\operatorname{tr}\left[T^{N}\right] \end{align*}Z​=σ1​=±1∑​σ2​=±1∑​⋯σN​=±1∑​i=1∏N​exp[Kσi​σi+1​+2h​(σi​+σi+1​)]≡tr[⟨σ1​∣T∣σ2​⟩⟨σ2​∣T∣σ3​⟩⋯⟨σN​∣T∣σ1​⟩]=tr[TN]​(6.9)​

where we have introduced the 2×22 \times 22×2 transfer matrix TTT, with elements

⟨σi∣T∣σj⟩=exp⁡[Kσiσj+h2(σi+σj)], i.e. T=(eK+he−Ke−KeK−h).(6.10)\left\langle\sigma_{i}\right| T\left|\sigma_{j}\right\rangle=\exp \left[K \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}+\frac{h}{2}\left(\sigma_{i}+\sigma_{j}\right)\right], \quad \text { i.e. } \quad T=\left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathrm{e}^{K+h} & \mathrm{e}^{-K} \tag{6.10}\\ \mathrm{e}^{-K} & \mathrm{e}^{K-h} \end{array}\right) .⟨σi​∣T∣σj​⟩=exp[Kσi​σj​+2h​(σi​+σj​)], i.e. T=(eK+he−K​e−KeK−h​).(6.10)

The expression for trace of the matrix can be evaluated in the basis that diagonalizes TTT, in which case it can be written in terms of the two eigenvalues λ±\lambda_{ \pm}λ±​as

Z=λ+N+λ−N=λ+N[1+(λ−/λ+)N]≈λ+N\begin{equation*} Z=\lambda_{+}^{N}+\lambda_{-}^{N}=\lambda_{+}^{N}\left[1+\left(\lambda_{-} / \lambda_{+}\right)^{N}\right] \approx \lambda_{+}^{N} \tag{6.11} \end{equation*}Z=λ+N​+λ−N​=λ+N​[1+(λ−​/λ+​)N]≈λ+N​​(6.11)​

We have assumed that λ+>λ−\lambda_{+}>\lambda_{-}λ+​>λ−​, and since in the limit of N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞ the larger eigenvalue dominates the sum, the free energy is

βf=−ln⁡Z/N=−ln⁡λ+.\begin{equation*} \beta f=-\ln Z / N=-\ln \lambda_{+} . \tag{6.12} \end{equation*}βf=−lnZ/N=−lnλ+​.​(6.12)​

Solving the characteristic equation, we find the eigenvalues

λ±=eKcosh⁡h±e2Ksinh⁡2h+e−2K\begin{equation*} \lambda_{ \pm}=\mathrm{e}^{K} \cosh h \pm \sqrt{\mathrm{e}^{2 K} \sinh ^{2} h+\mathrm{e}^{-2 K}} \tag{6.13} \end{equation*}λ±​=eKcoshh±e2Ksinh2h+e−2K​​(6.13)​

We shall leave a discussion of the singularities of the resulting free energy (at zero temperature) to the next section, and instead look at the averages and correlations in the limit of h=0h=0h=0.

To calculate the average of the spin at site iii, we need to evaluate

⟨σi⟩=1Z∑σ1=±1∑σ2=±1⋯∑σN=±1σi∏j=1Nexp⁡(Kσjσj+1)≡1Ztr⁡[⟨σ1∣T∣σ2⟩⋯⟨σi−1∣T∣σi⟩σi⟨σi∣T∣σi+1⟩⋯⟨σN∣T∣σ1⟩]=1Ztr⁡[Ti−1σ^zTN−i+1]=1Ztr⁡[TNσ^z]\begin{align*} \left\langle\sigma_{i}\right\rangle & =\frac{1}{Z} \sum_{\sigma_{1}= \pm 1} \sum_{\sigma_{2}= \pm 1} \cdots \sum_{\sigma_{N}= \pm 1} \sigma_{i} \prod_{j=1}^{N} \exp \left(K \sigma_{j} \sigma_{j+1}\right) \\ & \equiv \frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left[\left\langle\sigma_{1}\right| T\left|\sigma_{2}\right\rangle \cdots\left\langle\sigma_{i-1}\right| T\left|\sigma_{i}\right\rangle \sigma_{i}\left\langle\sigma_{i}\right| T\left|\sigma_{i+1}\right\rangle \cdots\left\langle\sigma_{N}\right| T\left|\sigma_{1}\right\rangle\right] \tag{6.14}\\ & =\frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left[T^{i-1} \widehat{\sigma}_{z} T^{N-i+1}\right] \\ & =\frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left[T^{N} \widehat{\sigma}_{z}\right] \end{align*}⟨σi​⟩​=Z1​σ1​=±1∑​σ2​=±1∑​⋯σN​=±1∑​σi​j=1∏N​exp(Kσj​σj+1​)≡Z1​tr[⟨σ1​∣T∣σ2​⟩⋯⟨σi−1​∣T∣σi​⟩σi​⟨σi​∣T∣σi+1​⟩⋯⟨σN​∣T∣σ1​⟩]=Z1​tr[Ti−1σz​TN−i+1]=Z1​tr[TNσz​]​(6.14)​

where have permuted the matrices inside the trace, and σ^z=(100−1)\widehat{\sigma}_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\right)σz​=(10​0−1​) is the usual 2×22 \times 22×2 Pauli matrix. One way to evaluate the final expression in Eq. (6.14) is to rotate to a basis where the matrix TTT is diagonal. For h=0h=0h=0, this is accomplished by the unitary matrix U=12(111−1)U=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1\end{array}\right)U=2​1​(11​1−1​), resulting in

⟨σi⟩=1Ztr⁡[(λ+N00λ−N)(0110)]=1Z(0λ+Nλ−N0)=0(6.15)\left\langle\sigma_{i}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left[\left(\begin{array}{cc} \lambda_{+}^{N} & 0 \tag{6.15}\\ 0 & \lambda_{-}^{N} \end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right)\right]=\frac{1}{Z}\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & \lambda_{+}^{N} \\ \lambda_{-}^{N} & 0 \end{array}\right)=0⟨σi​⟩=Z1​tr[(λ+N​0​0λ−N​​)(01​10​)]=Z1​(0λ−N​​λ+N​0​)=0(6.15)

Note that under this transformation the Pauli matrix σ^z\widehat{\sigma}_{z}σz​ is rotated into σ^x=\widehat{\sigma}_{x}=σx​= (0110)\left(\begin{array}{ll}0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0\end{array}\right)(01​10​).

The vanishing of the magnetization at zero field is of course expected by symmetry. A more interesting quantity is the two-spin correlation function

⟨σiσi+r⟩=1Z∑σ1=±1∑σ2=±1⋯∑σN=±1σiσi+r∏j=1Nexp⁡(Kσjσj+1)=1Ztr⁡[Ti−1σ^zTrσ^zTN−i−r+1]=1Ztr⁡[σ^zTrσ^zTN−r]\begin{align*} \left\langle\sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+r}\right\rangle & =\frac{1}{Z} \sum_{\sigma_{1}= \pm 1} \sum_{\sigma_{2}= \pm 1} \cdots \sum_{\sigma_{N}= \pm 1} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+r} \prod_{j=1}^{N} \exp \left(K \sigma_{j} \sigma_{j+1}\right) \tag{6.16}\\ & =\frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left[T^{i-1} \widehat{\sigma}_{z} T^{r} \widehat{\sigma}_{z} T^{N-i-r+1}\right]=\frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left[\widehat{\sigma}_{z} T^{r} \widehat{\sigma}_{z} T^{N-r}\right] \end{align*}⟨σi​σi+r​⟩​=Z1​σ1​=±1∑​σ2​=±1∑​⋯σN​=±1∑​σi​σi+r​j=1∏N​exp(Kσj​σj+1​)=Z1​tr[Ti−1σz​Trσz​TN−i−r+1]=Z1​tr[σz​Trσz​TN−r]​(6.16)​

Once again rotating to the basis where TTT is diagonal simplifies the trace to

⟨σiσi+r⟩=1Ztr⁡[(0110)(λ+r00λ−r)(0110)(λ+N−r00λ−N−r)]=1Ztr⁡(λ+N−rλ−r00λ−N−rλ+r)=λ+N−rλ−r+λ−N−rλ+rλ+N+λ−N.\begin{align*} \left\langle\sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+r}\right\rangle & =\frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left[\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc} \lambda_{+}^{r} & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_{-}^{r} \end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc} \lambda_{+}^{N-r} & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_{-}^{N-r} \end{array}\right)\right] \tag{6.17}\\ & =\frac{1}{Z} \operatorname{tr}\left(\begin{array}{cc} \lambda_{+}^{N-r} \lambda_{-}^{r} & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_{-}^{N-r} \lambda_{+}^{r} \end{array}\right)=\frac{\lambda_{+}^{N-r} \lambda_{-}^{r}+\lambda_{-}^{N-r} \lambda_{+}^{r}}{\lambda_{+}^{N}+\lambda_{-}^{N}} . \end{align*}⟨σi​σi+r​⟩​=Z1​tr[(01​10​)(λ+r​0​0λ−r​​)(01​10​)(λ+N−r​0​0λ−N−r​​)]=Z1​tr(λ+N−r​λ−r​0​0λ−N−r​λ+r​​)=λ+N​+λ−N​λ+N−r​λ−r​+λ−N−r​λ+r​​.​(6.17)​

Note that because of the periodic boundary conditions, the above answer is invariant under r→(N−r)r \rightarrow(N-r)r→(N−r). We are interested in the limit of N≫rN \gg rN≫r, for which

⟨σiσi+r⟩≈(λ−λ+)r≡e−r/ξ\begin{equation*} \left\langle\sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+r}\right\rangle \approx\left(\frac{\lambda_{-}}{\lambda_{+}}\right)^{r} \equiv \mathrm{e}^{-r / \xi} \tag{6.18} \end{equation*}⟨σi​σi+r​⟩≈(λ+​λ−​​)r≡e−r/ξ​(6.18)​

with the correlation length

ξ=[ln⁡(λ+λ−)]−1=−1ln⁡tanh⁡K\begin{equation*} \xi=\left[\ln \left(\frac{\lambda_{+}}{\lambda_{-}}\right)\right]^{-1}=-\frac{1}{\ln \tanh K} \tag{6.19} \end{equation*}ξ=[ln(λ−​λ+​​)]−1=−lntanhK1​​(6.19)​

The above transfer matrix approach can be generalized to any one dimensional chain with variables {si}\left\{s_{i}\right\}{si​} and nearest-neighbor interactions. The partition function can be written as

Z=∑{si}exp⁡[∑i=1NB(si,si+1)]=∑{si}∏i=1NeB(si,si+1),\begin{equation*} Z=\sum_{\left\{s_{i}\right\}} \exp \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N} B\left(s_{i}, s_{i+1}\right)\right]=\sum_{\left\{s_{i}\right\}} \prod_{i=1}^{N} \mathrm{e}^{B\left(s_{i}, s_{i+1}\right)}, \tag{6.20} \end{equation*}Z={si​}∑​exp[i=1∑N​B(si​,si+1​)]={si​}∑​i=1∏N​eB(si​,si+1​),​(6.20)​

where we have defined a transfer matrix TTT with elements,

⟨si∣T∣sj⟩=eB(si,sj)\begin{equation*} \left\langle s_{i}\right| T\left|s_{j}\right\rangle=\mathrm{e}^{B\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)} \tag{6.21} \end{equation*}⟨si​∣T∣sj​⟩=eB(si​,sj​)​(6.21)​

In the case of periodic boundary conditions, we then obtain

Z=tr⁡[TN]≈λmax⁡N.\begin{equation*} Z=\operatorname{tr}\left[T^{N}\right] \approx \lambda_{\max }^{N} . \tag{6.22} \end{equation*}Z=tr[TN]≈λmaxN​.​(6.22)​

Note that for N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞, the trace is dominated by the largest eigenvalue λmax⁡\lambda_{\max }λmax​. Quite generally the largest eigenvalue of the transfer matrix is related to the free energy, while the correlation lengths are obtained from ratios of eigenvalues. Frobenius' theorem states that for any finite matrix with finite positive elements, the largest eigenvalue is always non-degenerate. This implies that λmax⁡\lambda_{\max }λmax​ and ZZZ are analytic functions of the parameters appearing in BBB, and that one dimensional models can exhibit singularities (and hence a phase transition) only at zero temperature (when some matrix elements become infinite).

While the above formulation is framed in the language of discrete variables {si}\left\{s_{i}\right\}{si​}, the method can also be applied to continuous variables as illustrated by problems at the end of this chapter. As an example of the latter, let us consider three component unit spins s⃗i=(six,siy,siz)\vec{s}_{i}=\left(s_{i}^{x}, s_{i}^{y}, s_{i}^{z}\right)si​=(six​,siy​,siz​), with the Heisenberg model Hamiltonian

−βH=K∑i=1Ns⃗i⋅s⃗i+1\begin{equation*} -\beta \mathcal{H}=K \sum_{i=1}^{N} \vec{s}_{i} \cdot \vec{s}_{i+1} \tag{6.23} \end{equation*}−βH=Ki=1∑N​si​⋅si+1​​(6.23)​

Summing over all spin configurations, the partition function can be written as

Z=tr⁡s⃗i∑K∑i=1Ns⃗i⋅s⃗i+1=tr⁡s⃗iKs⃗1⋅s⃗2eKs⃗2⋅s⃗3⋯eKs⃗N⋅s⃗1=tr⁡TN\begin{equation*} Z=\operatorname{tr}_{\vec{s}_{i}} \sum^{K \sum_{i=1}^{N} \vec{s}_{i} \cdot \vec{s}_{i+1}}=\operatorname{tr}_{\vec{s}_{i}}^{K \vec{s}_{1} \cdot \vec{s}_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{K \vec{s}_{2} \cdot \vec{s}_{3}} \cdots \mathrm{e}^{K \vec{s}_{N} \cdot \vec{s}_{1}}=\operatorname{tr} T^{N} \tag{6.24} \end{equation*}Z=trsi​​∑K∑i=1N​si​⋅si+1​​=trsi​Ks1​⋅s2​​eKs2​⋅s3​⋯eKsN​⋅s1​=trTN​(6.24)​

where ⟨s⃗1∣T∣s⃗2⟩=eKs⃗1⋅s⃗2\left\langle\vec{s}_{1}\right| T\left|\vec{s}_{2}\right\rangle=\mathrm{e}^{K \vec{s}_{1} \cdot \vec{s}_{2}}⟨s1​∣T∣s2​⟩=eKs1​⋅s2​ is a transfer function. Quite generally we would like to bring TTT into the diagonal form ∑αλα∣α⟩⟨α∣\sum_{\alpha} \lambda_{\alpha}|\alpha\rangle\langle\alpha|∑α​λα​∣α⟩⟨α∣ (in Dirac notation), such that

⟨s⃗1∣T∣s⃗2⟩=∑αλα⟨s⃗1∣α⟩⟨α∣s⃗2⟩=∑αλαfα(s⃗1)fα∗(s⃗2).\begin{equation*} \left\langle\vec{s}_{1}\right| T\left|\vec{s}_{2}\right\rangle=\sum_{\alpha} \lambda_{\alpha}\left\langle\vec{s}_{1} \mid \alpha\right\rangle\left\langle\alpha \mid \vec{s}_{2}\right\rangle=\sum_{\alpha} \lambda_{\alpha} f_{\alpha}\left(\vec{s}_{1}\right) f_{\alpha}^{*}\left(\vec{s}_{2}\right) . \tag{6.25} \end{equation*}⟨s1​∣T∣s2​⟩=α∑​λα​⟨s1​∣α⟩⟨α∣s2​⟩=α∑​λα​fα​(s1​)fα∗​(s2​).​(6.25)​

From studies of plane waves in quantum mechanics you may recall that the exponential of a dot product can be decomposed in terms of the spherical harmonics YℓmY_{\ell m}Yℓm​. In particular,

eKs⃗1⋅s⃗2=∑ℓ=0∞∑m=−ℓℓ4πiℓjℓ(−iK)Yℓm∗(s⃗1)Yℓm(s⃗2)\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{K \vec{s}_{1} \cdot \vec{s}_{2}}=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} \sum_{m=-\ell}^{\ell} 4 \pi i^{\ell} j_{\ell}(-i K) Y_{\ell m}^{*}\left(\vec{s}_{1}\right) Y_{\ell m}\left(\vec{s}_{2}\right) \tag{6.26} \end{equation*}eKs1​⋅s2​=ℓ=0∑∞​m=−ℓ∑ℓ​4πiℓjℓ​(−iK)Yℓm∗​(s1​)Yℓm​(s2​)​(6.26)​

is precisely in the form of Eq. (6.25), from which we can read off the eigenvalues λℓm(K)=4πiℓjℓ(−iK)\lambda_{\ell m}(K)=4 \pi i^{\ell} j_{\ell}(-i K)λℓm​(K)=4πiℓjℓ​(−iK), which do not depend on mmm. The partition function is now given by

Z=tr⁡TN=∑ℓ=0∞∑m=−ℓℓλℓmN=∑ℓ=0∞(2ℓ+1)λℓN≈λ0N,\begin{equation*} Z=\operatorname{tr} T^{N}=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} \sum_{m=-\ell}^{\ell} \lambda_{\ell m}^{N}=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty}(2 \ell+1) \lambda_{\ell}^{N} \approx \lambda_{0}^{N}, \tag{6.27} \end{equation*}Z=trTN=ℓ=0∑∞​m=−ℓ∑ℓ​λℓmN​=ℓ=0∑∞​(2ℓ+1)λℓN​≈λ0N​,​(6.27)​

with λ0=4πj0(−iK)=4πsinh⁡K/K\lambda_{0}=4 \pi j_{0}(-i K)=4 \pi \sinh K / Kλ0​=4πj0​(−iK)=4πsinhK/K as the largest eigenvalue. The second largest eigenvalue is three fold degenerate, and given by λ1=4πj1(−iK)=\lambda_{1}=4 \pi j_{1}(-i K)=λ1​=4πj1​(−iK)= 4π[cosh⁡K/K−sinh⁡K/K2]4 \pi\left[\cosh K / K-\sinh K / K^{2}\right]4π[coshK/K−sinhK/K2].

6.3 Position space RG in one dimension

An exact RG treatment can be carried out for the Ising model with nearestneighbor interactions (Eq. 6.1) in one dimension. The basic idea is to find a transformation that reduces the number of degrees of freedom by a factor bbb, while preserving the partition function, i.e.

Z=∑{σi∣=1,⋯ ,N}e−βH[σi]=∑{σi′∣′=1,⋯ ,N/b}e−βH′[σi′]\begin{equation*} Z=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i} \mid=1, \cdots, N\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}\left[\sigma_{i}\right]}=\sum_{\left\{\left.\sigma_{i}^{\prime}\right|^{\prime}=1, \cdots, N / b\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}\left[\sigma_{i}^{\prime}\right]} \tag{6.28} \end{equation*}Z={σi​∣=1,⋯,N}∑​e−βH[σi​]={σi′​∣′=1,⋯,N/b}∑​e−βH′[σi′​]​(6.28)​

There are many mappings {σi}↦{σi′′}\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\} \mapsto\left\{\sigma_{i^{\prime}}^{\prime}\right\}{σi​}↦{σi′′​} that satisfy this condition. The choice of the transformation is therefore guided by the simplicity of the resulting RG. With b=2b=2b=2, for example, one possible choice is to group pairs of neighboring spins and define the renormalized spin as their average. This majority rule, σi′=(σ2i−1+σ2i)/2\sigma_{i}^{\prime}=\left(\sigma_{2 i-1}+\sigma_{2 i}\right) / 2σi′​=(σ2i−1​+σ2i​)/2, is in fact not very convenient as the new spin has three possible values (0,±1)(0, \pm 1)(0,±1) while the original spins are two valued. We can remove the ambiguity by assigning one of the two spins, e.g. σ2i−1\sigma_{2 i-1}σ2i−1​, the role of tiebreaker whenever the sum is zero. In this case the transformation is simply σi′=σ2i−1\sigma_{i}^{\prime}=\sigma_{2 i-1}σi′​=σ2i−1​. Such an RG procedure effectively removes the even numbered spins, si=σ2is_{i}=\sigma_{2 i}si​=σ2i​ and is usually called a decimation.

Fig. 6.3 Renormalization treatment of a one-dimensional chain via decimation by a factor of b=2b=2b=2.

Note that since σ′=±1\sigma^{\prime}= \pm 1σ′=±1 as in the original model, no renormalization factor ζ\zetaζ is necessary in this case. Since the interaction is over adjacent neighbors, the partition function can be written as

Z=∑{σi}Nexp⁡[∑i=1NB(σi,σi+1)]=∑{σi′}N/2∑{si}N/2exp⁡[∑i=1N/2[B(σi′,si)+B(si,σi+1′)]]\begin{equation*} Z=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}}^{N} \exp \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N} B\left(\sigma_{i}, \sigma_{i+1}\right)\right]=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}^{\prime}\right\}}^{N / 2} \sum_{\left\{s_{i}\right\}}^{N / 2} \exp \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N / 2}\left[B\left(\sigma_{i}^{\prime}, s_{i}\right)+B\left(s_{i}, \sigma_{i+1}^{\prime}\right)\right]\right] \tag{6.29} \end{equation*}Z={σi​}∑N​exp[i=1∑N​B(σi​,σi+1​)]={σi′​}∑N/2​{si​}∑N/2​exp​i=1∑N/2​[B(σi′​,si​)+B(si​,σi+1′​)]​​(6.29)​

Summing over the decimated spins, {si}\left\{s_{i}\right\}{si​}, leads to

e−βH′[σi′]≡∏i=1N/2[∑si=±1e[B(σi′,si)+B(si,σi+1′)]]≡e∑i=1N/2B′(σi′,σi+1′)\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}\left[\sigma_{i}^{\prime}\right]} \equiv \prod_{i=1}^{N / 2}\left[\sum_{s_{i}= \pm 1} \mathrm{e}^{\left[B\left(\sigma_{i}^{\prime}, s_{i}\right)+B\left(s_{i}, \sigma_{i+1}^{\prime}\right)\right]}\right] \equiv \mathrm{e}^{\sum_{i=1}^{N / 2} B^{\prime}\left(\sigma_{i}^{\prime}, \sigma_{i+1}^{\prime}\right)} \tag{6.30} \end{equation*}e−βH′[σi′​]≡i=1∏N/2​[si​=±1∑​e[B(σi′​,si​)+B(si​,σi+1′​)]]≡e∑i=1N/2​B′(σi′​,σi+1′​)​(6.30)​

where following Eq. (6.2)

B(σ1,σ2)=g+h2(σ1+σ2)+Kσ1σ2\begin{equation*} B\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right)=g+\frac{h}{2}\left(\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}\right)+K \sigma_{1} \sigma_{2} \tag{6.31} \end{equation*}B(σ1​,σ2​)=g+2h​(σ1​+σ2​)+Kσ1​σ2​​(6.31)​

and

B′(σ1′,σ2′)=g′+h′2(σ1′+σ2′)+K′σ1′σ2′\begin{equation*} B^{\prime}\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}, \sigma_{2}^{\prime}\right)=g^{\prime}+\frac{h^{\prime}}{2}\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime}\right)+K^{\prime} \sigma_{1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2}^{\prime} \tag{6.32} \end{equation*}B′(σ1′​,σ2′​)=g′+2h′​(σ1′​+σ2′​)+K′σ1′​σ2′​​(6.32)​

are the most general interaction forms for Ising spins. Following Eq. (6.30), the renormalized interactions are obtained from

R(σ1′,σ2′)≡exp⁡[K′σ1′σ2′+h′2(σ1′+σ2′)+g′]=∑s1=±1exp⁡[Ks1(σ1′+σ2′)+h2(σ1′+σ2′)+hs1+2g]\begin{align*} R\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}, \sigma_{2}^{\prime}\right) & \equiv \exp \left[K^{\prime} \sigma_{1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2}^{\prime}+\frac{h^{\prime}}{2}\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime}\right)+g^{\prime}\right] \\ & =\sum_{s_{1}= \pm 1} \exp \left[K s_{1}\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime}\right)+\frac{h}{2}\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime}\right)+h s_{1}+2 g\right] \tag{6.33} \end{align*}R(σ1′​,σ2′​)​≡exp[K′σ1′​σ2′​+2h′​(σ1′​+σ2′​)+g′]=s1​=±1∑​exp[Ks1​(σ1′​+σ2′​)+2h​(σ1′​+σ2′​)+hs1​+2g]​(6.33)​

To solve for the renormalized interactions it is convenient to set

{x=eK,y=eh,z=egx′=eK′,y′=eh′,z′=eg′.(6.34)\left\{\begin{array}{l} x=\mathrm{e}^{K}, \quad y=\mathrm{e}^{h}, \quad z=\mathrm{e}^{g} \tag{6.34}\\ x^{\prime}=\mathrm{e}^{K^{\prime}}, \quad y^{\prime}=\mathrm{e}^{h^{\prime}}, \quad z^{\prime}=\mathrm{e}^{g^{\prime}} . \end{array}\right.{x=eK,y=eh,z=egx′=eK′,y′=eh′,z′=eg′.​(6.34)

The four possible configurations of the bond are

{R(+,+)=x′y′z′=z2y(x2y+x−2y−1)R(−,−)=x′y′−1z′=z2y−1(x−2y+x2y−1)R(+,−)=x′−1z′=z2(y+y−1)R(−,+)=x′−1z′=z2(y+y−1)(6.35)\left\{\begin{array}{l} R(+,+)=x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}=z^{2} y\left(x^{2} y+x^{-2} y^{-1}\right) \tag{6.35}\\ R(-,-)=x^{\prime} y^{\prime-1} z^{\prime}=z^{2} y^{-1}\left(x^{-2} y+x^{2} y^{-1}\right) \\ R(+,-)=x^{\prime-1} z^{\prime}=z^{2}\left(y+y^{-1}\right) \\ R(-,+)=x^{\prime-1} z^{\prime}=z^{2}\left(y+y^{-1}\right) \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​R(+,+)=x′y′z′=z2y(x2y+x−2y−1)R(−,−)=x′y′−1z′=z2y−1(x−2y+x2y−1)R(+,−)=x′−1z′=z2(y+y−1)R(−,+)=x′−1z′=z2(y+y−1)​(6.35)

The last two equations are identical, resulting in three equations in three unknowns, with the solutions,

{z′4=z8(x2y+x−2y−1)(x−2y+x2y−1)(y+y−1)2y′2=y2x2y+x−2y−1x−2y+x2y−1x′4=(x2y+x−2y−1)(x−2y+x2y−1)(y+y−1)2(6.36)\left\{\begin{array}{l} z^{\prime 4}=z^{8}\left(x^{2} y+x^{-2} y^{-1}\right)\left(x^{-2} y+x^{2} y^{-1}\right)\left(y+y^{-1}\right)^{2} \tag{6.36}\\ y^{\prime 2}=y^{2} \frac{x^{2} y+x^{-2} y^{-1}}{x^{-2} y+x^{2} y^{-1}} \\ x^{\prime 4}=\frac{\left(x^{2} y+x^{-2} y^{-1}\right)\left(x^{-2} y+x^{2} y^{-1}\right)}{\left(y+y^{-1}\right)^{2}} \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​z′4=z8(x2y+x−2y−1)(x−2y+x2y−1)(y+y−1)2y′2=y2x−2y+x2y−1x2y+x−2y−1​x′4=(y+y−1)2(x2y+x−2y−1)(x−2y+x2y−1)​​(6.36)

Taking the logarithms, we find recursion relations of the form

{g′=2g+δg(K,h)h′=h+δh(K,h)K′=K′(K,h).(6.37)\left\{\begin{array}{l} g^{\prime}=2 g+\delta g(K, h) \tag{6.37}\\ h^{\prime}=h+\delta h(K, h) \\ K^{\prime}=K^{\prime}(K, h) . \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​g′=2g+δg(K,h)h′=h+δh(K,h)K′=K′(K,h).​(6.37)

The parameter ggg is just an additive constant to the Hamiltonian. It does not affect the probabilities and hence does not appear in the recursion relations for KKK and h;δg(K,h)h ; \delta g(K, h)h;δg(K,h) is the contribution of the decimated spins to the overall free energy.

Fig. 6.4 Fixed points and RG flows for the coupling KKK in one dimension.

Fig. 6.5 Fixed points and RG flows in the space of coupling (tanh h,tanh⁡Kh, \tanh Kh,tanhK ) in one dimension. (1) Fixed points: The h=0h=0h=0 subspace is closed by symmetry, and it can be checked that for y=1y=1y=1 Eqs. (6.36) imply y′=1y^{\prime}=1y′=1, and

e4K′=(e2K+e−2K2)2,⟹K′=12ln⁡cosh⁡2K\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{4 K^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{2 K}+\mathrm{e}^{-2 K}}{2}\right)^{2}, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad K^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \cosh 2 K \tag{6.38} \end{equation*}e4K′=(2e2K+e−2K​)2,⟹K′=21​lncosh2K​(6.38)​

The recursion relation for KKK has the following fixed points: (a) An infinite temperature fixed point at K∗=0K^{*}=0K∗=0, which is the sink for the disordered phase. If KKK is small, K′≈ln⁡(1+4K2/2)/2≈K2K^{\prime} \approx \ln \left(1+4 K^{2} / 2\right) / 2 \approx K^{2}K′≈ln(1+4K2/2)/2≈K2, is even smaller, indicating that this is a stable fixed point with zero correlation length. (b) A zero temperature fixed point at K∗→∞K^{*} \rightarrow \inftyK∗→∞, describing the ordered phase. For a large but finite KKK, the renormalized interaction K′≈ln⁡(e2K/2)/2≈K−ln⁡2/2K^{\prime} \approx \ln \left(\mathrm{e}^{2 K} / 2\right) / 2 \approx K-\ln 2 / 2K′≈ln(e2K/2)/2≈K−ln2/2 is somewhat smaller. This fixed point is thus unstable with an infinite correlation length.

Clearly any finite interaction renormalizes to zero, indicating that the onedimensional chain is always disordered at sufficiently long length scales. The absence of any other fixed point is apparent by noting that the recursion relation of Eq. (6.38) can alternatively be written as tanh⁡K′=(tanh⁡K)2\tanh K^{\prime}=(\tanh K)^{2}tanhK′=(tanhK)2. (2) Flow diagrams indicate that in the presence of a field hhh, all flows terminate on a line of fixed points with K∗=0K^{*}=0K∗=0 and arbitrary h∗h^{*}h∗. These fixed points describe independent spins and all have zero correlation length. The flows originate from the fixed point at h∗=0h^{*}=0h∗=0 and K∗→∞K^{*} \rightarrow \inftyK∗→∞ which has two unstable directions in the (K,h)(K, h)(K,h) parameter space. (3) Linearizing the recursion relations around this fixed point (x→∞)(x \rightarrow \infty)(x→∞) yields

{x′4≈x4/4y′2≈y4⟹{e−K′=2e−Kh′=2h.(6.39)\left\{\begin{array} { l } { x ^ { \prime 4 } \approx x ^ { 4 } / 4 } \tag{6.39}\\ { y ^ { \prime 2 } \approx y ^ { 4 } } \end{array} \Longrightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{e}^{-K^{\prime}}=\sqrt{2} \mathrm{e}^{-K} \\ h^{\prime}=2 h . \end{array}\right.\right.{x′4≈x4/4y′2≈y4​⟹{e−K′=2​e−Kh′=2h.​(6.39)

We can thus regard e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K and hhh as scaling fields. Since ξ′=ξ/2\xi^{\prime}=\xi / 2ξ′=ξ/2, the correlation length in the vicinity of the fixed point satisfies the homogeneous form (b=2)(b=2)(b=2)

ξ(e−K,h)=2ξ(2e−K,2h)=2ℓξ(2ℓ/2e−K,2ℓh).\begin{align*} \xi\left(\mathrm{e}^{-K}, h\right) & =2 \xi\left(\sqrt{2} \mathrm{e}^{-K}, 2 h\right) \tag{6.40}\\ & =2^{\ell} \xi\left(2^{\ell / 2} \mathrm{e}^{-K}, 2^{\ell} h\right) . \end{align*}ξ(e−K,h)​=2ξ(2​e−K,2h)=2ℓξ(2ℓ/2e−K,2ℓh).​(6.40)​

The second equation is obtained by repeating the RG procedure ℓ\ellℓ times. Choosing ℓ\ellℓ such that 2ℓ/2e−K≈12^{\ell / 2} \mathrm{e}^{-K} \approx 12ℓ/2e−K≈1, we obtain the scaling form

ξ(e−K,h)=e2Kgξ(he2K)\begin{equation*} \xi\left(\mathrm{e}^{-K}, h\right)=\mathrm{e}^{2 K} g_{\xi}\left(h \mathrm{e}^{2 K}\right) \tag{6.41} \end{equation*}ξ(e−K,h)=e2Kgξ​(he2K)​(6.41)​

The correlation length diverges on approaching T=0T=0T=0 for h=0h=0h=0. However, its divergence is not a power law of temperature. There is thus an ambiguity in identifying the exponent ν\nuν related to the choice of the measure of vicinity to T=0(1/KT=0\left(1 / K\right.T=0(1/K or e−K)\left.\mathrm{e}^{-K}\right)e−K).

The hyperscaling assumption states that the singular part of the free energy in ddd dimensions is proportional to ξ−d\xi^{-d}ξ−d. Hence we expect

fsing (K,h)∝ξ−1=e−2Kgf(he2K).\begin{equation*} f_{\text {sing }}(K, h) \propto \xi^{-1}=\mathrm{e}^{-2 K} g_{f}\left(h \mathrm{e}^{2 K}\right) . \tag{6.42} \end{equation*}fsing ​(K,h)∝ξ−1=e−2Kgf​(he2K).​(6.42)​

At zero field, the magnetization is always zero, while the susceptibility behaves as

χ(K)∼∂2f∂2h∣h=0∼e2K.\begin{equation*} \left.\chi(K) \sim \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial^{2} h}\right|_{h=0} \sim \mathrm{e}^{2 K} . \tag{6.43} \end{equation*}χ(K)∼∂2h∂2f​​h=0​∼e2K.​(6.43)​

On approaching zero temperature, the divergence of the susceptibility is proportional to that of the correlation length. Using the general forms, ⟨si,si+x⟩∼\left\langle s_{i}, s_{i+x}\right\rangle \sim⟨si​,si+x​⟩∼ e−x/ξ/xd−2+η\mathrm{e}^{-x / \xi} / x^{d-2+\eta}e−x/ξ/xd−2+η, and χ∼∫ddx⟨s0sx⟩c∼ξ2−η\chi \sim \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left\langle s_{0} s_{\mathbf{x}}\right\rangle_{c} \sim \xi^{2-\eta}χ∼∫ddx⟨s0​sx​⟩c​∼ξ2−η, we conclude that η=1\eta=1η=1.

The transfer matrix method also provides an alternative RG scheme for all general one-dimensional chains with nearest-neighbor interactions. For decimation by a factor bbb, we can use Z=tr⁡[(Tb)N/b]Z=\operatorname{tr}\left[\left(T^{b}\right)^{N / b}\right]Z=tr[(Tb)N/b] to construct the rescaled bond energy from

eB(si′,sj′)≡⟨si′∣T′∣sj′⟩=⟨si′∣Tb∣sj′⟩.\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{B\left(s_{i}^{\prime}, s_{j}^{\prime}\right)} \equiv\left\langle s_{i}^{\prime}\right| T^{\prime}\left|s_{j}^{\prime}\right\rangle=\left\langle s_{i}^{\prime}\right| T^{b}\left|s_{j}^{\prime}\right\rangle . \tag{6.44} \end{equation*}eB(si′​,sj′​)≡⟨si′​∣T′​sj′​⟩=⟨si′​∣Tb​sj′​⟩.​(6.44)​

Fig. 6.6 The susceptibility (and correlation length) diverge similarly at zero temperature in the one-dimensional Ising model.

6.4 The Niemeijer-van Leeuwen cumulant approximation

Unfortunately, the decimation procedure cannot be performed exactly in higher dimensions. For example, the square lattice can be divided into two sublattices. For an RG with b=2b=\sqrt{2}b=2​, we can start by decimating the spins on one sublattice. The interactions between the four spins surrounding each decimated spin are obtained by generalizing Eq. (6.33). If initially h=g=0h=g=0h=g=0, we obtain

R(σ1′,σ2′,σ3′,σ4′)=∑s=±1eKs(σ1′+σ2′+σ3′+σ4′)=2cosh⁡[K(σ1′+σ2′+σ3′+σ4′)]\begin{equation*} R\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}, \sigma_{2}^{\prime}, \sigma_{3}^{\prime}, \sigma_{4}^{\prime}\right)=\sum_{s= \pm 1} \mathrm{e}^{K s\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime}+\sigma_{3}^{\prime}+\sigma_{4}^{\prime}\right)}=2 \cosh \left[K\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime}+\sigma_{3}^{\prime}+\sigma_{4}^{\prime}\right)\right] \tag{6.45} \end{equation*}R(σ1′​,σ2′​,σ3′​,σ4′​)=s=±1∑​eKs(σ1′​+σ2′​+σ3′​+σ4′​)=2cosh[K(σ1′​+σ2′​+σ3′​+σ4′​)]​(6.45)​

Clearly the four spins appear symmetrically in the above expression, and hence are subject to the same two-body interaction. This implies that new interactions along the diagonals of the renormalized lattice are also generated, and the nearest-neighbor form of the original Hamiltonian is not preserved. There is also a four-point interaction, and R=exp⁡[g′+K′(σ1′σ2′+σ2′σ3′+σ3′σ4′+σ4′σ1′+σ1′σ3′+σ2′σ4′)+K4′σ1′σ2′σ3′σ4′]R=\exp \left[g^{\prime}+K^{\prime}\left(\sigma_{1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime} \sigma_{3}^{\prime}+\sigma_{3}^{\prime} \sigma_{4}^{\prime}+\sigma_{4}^{\prime} \sigma_{1}^{\prime}+\sigma_{1}^{\prime} \sigma_{3}^{\prime}+\sigma_{2}^{\prime} \sigma_{4}^{\prime}\right)+K_{4}^{\prime} \sigma_{1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2}^{\prime} \sigma_{3}^{\prime} \sigma_{4}^{\prime}\right]R=exp[g′+K′(σ1′​σ2′​+σ2′​σ3′​+σ3′​σ4′​+σ4′​σ1′​+σ1′​σ3′​+σ2′​σ4′​)+K4′​σ1′​σ2′​σ3′​σ4′​]. The number (and range) of new interactions increases with each RG step, and some truncating approximation is necessary. Two such schemes are described in the following sections.

One of the earliest approaches was developed by Niemeijer and van Leeuwen (NvL)(\mathrm{NvL})(NvL) for treating the Ising model on a triangular lattice, subject to the usual nearest-neighbor Hamiltonian −βH=K∑⟨ij⟩σiσj-\beta \mathcal{H}=K \sum_{\langle i j\rangle} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}−βH=K∑⟨ij⟩​σi​σj​. The original lattice sites are grouped into cells of three spins (e.g. in alternating up pointing triangles). Labeling the three spins in cell α\alphaα as {σα1,σα2,σα3}\left\{\sigma_{\alpha}^{1}, \sigma_{\alpha}^{2}, \sigma_{\alpha}^{3}\right\}{σα1​,σα2​,σα3​}, we can use a majority rule to define the renormalized cell spin as

σα′=sign⁡[σα1+σα2+σα3].\begin{equation*} \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}=\operatorname{sign}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{1}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{2}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{3}\right] . \tag{6.47} \end{equation*}σα′​=sign[σα1​+σα2​+σα3​].​(6.47)​

(There is no ambiguity in the rule for any odd number of sites, and the renormalized spin is two-valued.) The renormalized interactions corresponding to the above map are obtained from the constrained sum

e−βH′[σα′]=∑{σα′↛σα′}′e−βH[σαi]\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]}=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime} \nrightarrow \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right\}}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{i}\right]} \tag{6.48} \end{equation*}e−βH′[σα′​]={σα′​↛σα′​}∑′​e−βH[σαi​]​(6.48)​

Fig. 6.8 Each cell spin is assigned from the majority of its three site spins.

To truncate the number of interactions in the renormalized Hamiltonian, NvL introduced a perturbative scheme by setting βH=βH0+U\beta \mathcal{H}=\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}+\mathcal{U}βH=βH0​+U. The unperturbed Hamiltonian

−βH0=K∑α(σα1σα2+σα2σα3+σα3σα1)\begin{equation*} -\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}=K \sum_{\alpha}\left(\sigma_{\alpha}^{1} \sigma_{\alpha}^{2}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{2} \sigma_{\alpha}^{3}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{3} \sigma_{\alpha}^{1}\right) \tag{6.49} \end{equation*}−βH0​=Kα∑​(σα1​σα2​+σα2​σα3​+σα3​σα1​)​(6.49)​

involves only intracell interactions. Since the cells are decoupled, this part of the Hamiltonian can be treated exactly. The remaining intercell interactions are treated as a perturbation

−U=K∑⟨α,β⟩(σβ(1)σα(2)+σβ(1)σα(3)).\begin{equation*} -\mathcal{U}=K \sum_{\langle\alpha, \beta\rangle}\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{(1)} \sigma_{\alpha}^{(2)}+\sigma_{\beta}^{(1)} \sigma_{\alpha}^{(3)}\right) . \tag{6.50} \end{equation*}−U=K⟨α,β⟩∑​(σβ(1)​σα(2)​+σβ(1)​σα(3)​).​(6.50)​

The sum is over all neighboring cells, each connected by two bonds. (The actual spins involved depend on the relative orientations of the cells.) Equation (6.48) is now evaluated perturbatively as

e−βH′[σα′]=∑{σα↔σα′}′e−βH0[σαi][1−U+U22−⋯ ]\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]}=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{\alpha} \leftrightarrow \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right\}}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{i}\right]}\left[1-\mathcal{U}+\frac{\mathcal{U}^{2}}{2}-\cdots\right] \tag{6.51} \end{equation*}e−βH′[σα′​]={σα​↔σα′​}∑′​e−βH0​[σαi​][1−U+2U2​−⋯]​(6.51)​

The renormalized Hamiltonian is given by the cumulant series

βH′[σα′]=−ln⁡Z0[σα′]+⟨U⟩0−12(⟨U2⟩0−⟨U⟩02)+O(U3)\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]=-\ln Z_{0}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]+\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\langle\mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{0}-\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}^{2}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\mathcal{U}^{3}\right) \tag{6.52} \end{equation*}βH′[σα′​]=−lnZ0​[σα′​]+⟨U⟩0​−21​(⟨U2⟩0​−⟨U⟩02​)+O(U3)​(6.52)​

where ⟩0\left\rangle_{0}\right.⟩0​ refers to the expectation values with respect to βH0\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}βH0​, with the restriction of fixed [σα′]\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right][σα′​], and Z0Z_{0}Z0​ is the corresponding partition function.

To proceed, we construct a table of all possible configurations of spins within a cell, their renormalized value, and contribution to the cell energy:

σα′\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}σα′​ σα1\sigma_{\alpha}^{1}σα1​ σα2\sigma_{\alpha}^{2}σα2​ σα3\sigma_{\alpha}^{3}σα3​ exp⁡[−βH0]\exp \left[-\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}\right]exp[−βH0​]
+ + + + e3K\mathrm{e}^{3 K}e3K
+ - + + e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K
+ + - + e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K
+ + + - e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K
- - - - e3K\mathrm{e}^{3 K}e3K
- + - - e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K
- - + - e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K
- - - + e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K

The restricted partition function is the product of contributions from the independent cells,

Z0[σα′]=∏α[∑{σασα↛σα′}eK(σα1σα2+σα2σα3+σα3σα1)]=(e3K+3e−K)N/3.\begin{equation*} Z_{0}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]=\prod_{\alpha}\left[\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{\alpha}^{\left.\sigma_{\alpha} \nrightarrow \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right\}}\right.} \mathrm{e}^{K\left(\sigma_{\alpha}^{1} \sigma_{\alpha}^{2}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{2} \sigma_{\alpha}^{3}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{3} \sigma_{\alpha}^{1}\right)}\right]=\left(\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}\right)^{N / 3} . \tag{6.53} \end{equation*}Z0​[σα′​]=α∏​​{σασα​↛σα′​}​∑​eK(σα1​σα2​+σα2​σα3​+σα3​σα1​)​=(e3K+3e−K)N/3.​(6.53)​

It is independent of [σα′]\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right][σα′​], thus contributing an additive constant to the Hamiltonian. The first cumulant of the interaction is

−⟨U⟩0=K∑⟨α,β⟩[⟨σβ1⟩0⟨σα2⟩0+⟨σβ1⟩0⟨σα3⟩0]=2K∑⟨α,β⟩⟨σαi⟩0⟨σβj⟩0,\begin{equation*} -\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}=K \sum_{\langle\alpha, \beta\rangle}\left[\left\langle\sigma_{\beta}^{1}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle\sigma_{\alpha}^{2}\right\rangle_{0}+\left\langle\sigma_{\beta}^{1}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle\sigma_{\alpha}^{3}\right\rangle_{0}\right]=2 K \sum_{\langle\alpha, \beta\rangle}\left\langle\sigma_{\alpha}^{i}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle\sigma_{\beta}^{j}\right\rangle_{0}, \tag{6.54} \end{equation*}−⟨U⟩0​=K⟨α,β⟩∑​[⟨σβ1​⟩0​⟨σα2​⟩0​+⟨σβ1​⟩0​⟨σα3​⟩0​]=2K⟨α,β⟩∑​⟨σαi​⟩0​⟨σβj​⟩0​,​(6.54)​

where we have taken advantage of the equivalence of the three spins in each cell. Using the table, we can evaluate the restricted average of site spins as

⟨σαi⟩0={+e3K−e−K+2e−Ke3K+3e−K for σα′=+1−e3K+e−K−2e−Ke3K+3e−K for σα′=−1}≡e3K+e−Ke3K+3e−Kσα′.(6.55)\left\langle\sigma_{\alpha}^{i}\right\rangle_{0}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} \frac{+\mathrm{e}^{3 K}-\mathrm{e}^{-K}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-K}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}} & \text { for } \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}=+1 \tag{6.55}\\ \frac{-\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+\mathrm{e}^{-K}-2 \mathrm{e}^{-K}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}} & \text { for } \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}=-1 \end{array}\right\} \equiv \frac{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+\mathrm{e}^{-K}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}} \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime} .⟨σαi​⟩0​={e3K+3e−K+e3K−e−K+2e−K​e3K+3e−K−e3K+e−K−2e−K​​ for σα′​=+1 for σα′​=−1​}≡e3K+3e−Ke3K+e−K​σα′​.(6.55)

Substituting in Eq. (6.54) leads to

−βH′[σα′]=N3ln⁡(e3K+3e−K)+2K(e3K+e−Ke3K+3e−K)2∑⟨αβ⟩σα′σβ′+O(U2).\begin{equation*} -\beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}\left[\sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]=\frac{N}{3} \ln \left(\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}\right)+2 K\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+\mathrm{e}^{-K}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}}\right)^{2} \sum_{\langle\alpha \beta\rangle} \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime} \sigma_{\beta}^{\prime}+\mathcal{O}\left(\mathcal{U}^{2}\right) . \tag{6.56} \end{equation*}−βH′[σα′​]=3N​ln(e3K+3e−K)+2K(e3K+3e−Ke3K+e−K​)2⟨αβ⟩∑​σα′​σβ′​+O(U2).​(6.56)​

At this order, the renormalized Hamiltonian involves only nearest-neighbor interactions, with the recursion relation

K′=2K(e3K+e−Ke3K+3e−K)2.\begin{equation*} K^{\prime}=2 K\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+\mathrm{e}^{-K}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}}\right)^{2} . \tag{6.57} \end{equation*}K′=2K(e3K+3e−Ke3K+e−K​)2.​(6.57)​

(1) Equation (6.57) has the following fixed points: (a) The high-temperature sink at K∗=0K^{*}=0K∗=0. If K≪1,K′≈2K(2/4)2=K/2<KK \ll 1, K^{\prime} \approx 2 K(2 / 4)^{2}=K / 2<KK≪1,K′≈2K(2/4)2=K/2<K, i.e. this fixed point is stable, and has zero correlation length. (b) The low-temperature sink at K∗=∞K^{*}=\inftyK∗=∞. If K≫1K \gg 1K≫1, then K′≈2K>KK^{\prime} \approx 2 K>KK′≈2K>K, i.e. unlike the one-dimensional case, this fixed point is also stable with zero correlation length. (c) Since both of the above fixed points are stable, there must be at least one unstable fixed point at finite K′=K=K∗K^{\prime}=K=K^{*}K′=K=K∗. From Eq. (6.57), the fixed point position satisfies

12=e3K∗+e−K∗e3K∗+3e−K∗,⟹2e4K∗+2=e4K∗+3.\begin{equation*} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{e}^{3 K^{*}}+\mathrm{e}^{-K^{*}}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K^{*}}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K^{*}}}, \Longrightarrow \sqrt{2} \mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+\sqrt{2}=\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+3 . \tag{6.58} \end{equation*}2​1​=e3K∗+3e−K∗e3K∗+e−K∗​,⟹2​e4K∗+2​=e4K∗+3.​(6.58)​

The fixed point value

K∗=14ln⁡(3−22−1)≈0.3356\begin{equation*} K^{*}=\frac{1}{4} \ln \left(\frac{3-\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}-1}\right) \approx 0.3356 \tag{6.59} \end{equation*}K∗=41​ln(2​−13−2​​)≈0.3356​(6.59)​

can be compared to the exactly known value of 0.2747 for the triangular lattice. (2) Linearizing the recursion relation around the non-trivial fixed point yields,

∂K′∂K∣K∗=2(e4K∗+1e4K∗+3)2+32K∗e4K∗(e4K∗+1)(e4K∗+3)3≈1.624\begin{equation*} \left.\frac{\partial K^{\prime}}{\partial K}\right|_{K^{*}}=2\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+1}{\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+3}\right)^{2}+32 K^{*} \mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}} \frac{\left(\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+1\right)}{\left(\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+3\right)^{3}} \approx 1.624 \tag{6.60} \end{equation*}∂K∂K′​​K∗​=2(e4K∗+3e4K∗+1​)2+32K∗e4K∗(e4K∗+3)3(e4K∗+1)​≈1.624​(6.60)​

The fixed point is indeed unstable as required by the continuity of flows. This RG scheme removes 1/31 / 31/3 of the degrees of freedom, and corresponds to b=3b=\sqrt{3}b=3​. The thermal eigenvalue is thus obtained as

byt=∂K′∂K∣K∗⟹yt≈ln⁡(1.624)ln⁡(3)≈0.883\begin{equation*} b^{y_{t}}=\left.\frac{\partial K^{\prime}}{\partial K}\right|_{K^{*}} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad y_{t} \approx \frac{\ln (1.624)}{\ln (\sqrt{3})} \approx 0.883 \tag{6.61} \end{equation*}byt​=∂K∂K′​​K∗​⟹yt​≈ln(3​)ln(1.624)​≈0.883​(6.61)​

This can be compared to the exactly known value of yt=1y_{t}=1yt​=1, for the two-dimensional Ising model. It is certainly better than the mean-field (Gaussian) estimate of yt=2y_{t}=2yt​=2. From this eigenvalue we can estimate the exponents

ν=1/yt≈1.13(1), and α=2−2/yt=−0.26(0)\nu=1 / y_{t} \approx 1.13 \quad(1), \quad \text { and } \quad \alpha=2-2 / y_{t}=-0.26 \quad(0)ν=1/yt​≈1.13(1), and α=2−2/yt​=−0.26(0)

where the exact values are given in the brackets. (3) To complete the calculation of exponents, we need the magnetic eigenvalue yhy_{h}yh​, obtained after adding a magnetic field to the Hamiltonian, i.e. from

βH=βH0+U−h∑iσαi\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}=\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}+\mathcal{U}-h \sum_{i} \sigma_{\alpha}^{i} \tag{6.62} \end{equation*}βH=βH0​+U−hi∑​σαi​​(6.62)​

Fig. 6.9 Fixed points and RG flows for the coupling KKK in two dimensions.

Since the fixed point occurs for h∗=0h^{*}=0h∗=0, the added term can also be treated perturbatively, and to the lowest order

βH′=βH0+⟨U⟩0−h∑α⟨(σα1+σα2+σα3)⟩0\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}=\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}+\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}-h \sum_{\alpha}\left\langle\left(\sigma_{\alpha}^{1}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{2}+\sigma_{\alpha}^{3}\right)\right\rangle_{0} \tag{6.63} \end{equation*}βH′=βH0​+⟨U⟩0​−hα∑​⟨(σα1​+σα2​+σα3​)⟩0​​(6.63)​

where the spins are grouped according to their cells. Using Eq. (6.55),

βH′=ln⁡Z0+K′∑⟨α,β⟩σα′σβ′−3h∑α(e3K+e−Ke3K+3e−K)σα′,\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}=\ln Z_{0}+K^{\prime} \sum_{\langle\alpha, \beta\rangle} \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime} \sigma_{\beta}^{\prime}-3 h \sum_{\alpha}\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+\mathrm{e}^{-K}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}}\right) \sigma_{\alpha}^{\prime}, \tag{6.64} \end{equation*}βH′=lnZ0​+K′⟨α,β⟩∑​σα′​σβ′​−3hα∑​(e3K+3e−Ke3K+e−K​)σα′​,​(6.64)​

thus identifying the renormalized magnetic field as

h′=3h(e3K+e−Ke3K+3e−K).\begin{equation*} h^{\prime}=3 h\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+\mathrm{e}^{-K}}{\mathrm{e}^{3 K}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-K}}\right) . \tag{6.65} \end{equation*}h′=3h(e3K+3e−Ke3K+e−K​).​(6.65)​

In the vicinity of the unstable fixed point

byh=∂h′∂h∣K∗=3e4K∗+1e4K∗+3=32,\begin{equation*} b^{y_{h}}=\left.\frac{\partial h^{\prime}}{\partial h}\right|_{K^{*}}=3 \frac{\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+1}{\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+3}=\frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}, \tag{6.66} \end{equation*}byh​=∂h∂h′​​K∗​=3e4K∗+3e4K∗+1​=2​3​,​(6.66)​

and

yh=ln⁡(3/2)ln⁡(3)≈1.37\begin{equation*} y_{h}=\frac{\ln (3 / \sqrt{2})}{\ln (\sqrt{3})} \approx 1.37 \tag{6.67} \end{equation*}yh​=ln(3​)ln(3/2​)​≈1.37​(6.67)​

This is lower than the exact value of yh=1.875y_{h}=1.875yh​=1.875. (The Gaussian value of yh=2y_{h}=2yh​=2 is closer to the correct result in this case.) (4) NvL carried out the approach to the second order in U\mathcal{U}U. At this order two additional interactions over further neighbor spins are generated. The recursion relations in this three parameter space have a non-trivial fixed point with one unstable direction. The resulting eigenvalue of yt=1.053y_{t}=1.053yt​=1.053 is tantalizingly close to the exact value of 1 , but this agreement is likely accidental.

6.5 The Migdal-Kadanoff bond moving approximation

Consider a b=2RGb=2 \mathrm{RG}b=2RG for the Ising model on a square lattice, in which every other spin along each lattice direction is decimated. As noted earlier, such decimation generates new interactions between the remaining spins. One way of overcoming this difficulty is to simply remove the bonds not connected to the retained spins. The renormalized spins are then connected to their nearest neighbors by two successive bonds. Clearly after decimation, the renormalized bond is given by the recursion relation in Eq. (6.38), characteristic of a one dimensional chain. The approximation of simply removing the unwanted bonds weakens the system to the extent that it behaves one dimensionally. This is remedied by using the unwanted bonds to strengthen those that are left behind. The spins that are retained are now connected by a pair of double bonds (of strength 2K2 K2K ), and the decimation leads to

K′=12ln⁡cosh⁡(2×2K)\begin{equation*} K^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \cosh (2 \times 2 K) \tag{6.68} \end{equation*}K′=21​lncosh(2×2K)​(6.68)​

(1) Fixed points of this recursion relation are located at (a) K∗=0K^{*}=0K∗=0 : For K≪1,K′≈ln⁡(1+8K2)/2≈4K2≪KK \ll 1, K^{\prime} \approx \ln \left(1+8 K^{2}\right) / 2 \approx 4 K^{2} \ll KK≪1,K′≈ln(1+8K2)/2≈4K2≪K, i.e. this fixed point is stable. (b) K∗→∞K^{*} \rightarrow \inftyK∗→∞ : For K≫1,K′≈ln⁡(e4K/2)/2≈2K≫KK \gg 1, K^{\prime} \approx \ln \left(\mathrm{e}^{4 K} / 2\right) / 2 \approx 2 K \gg KK≫1,K′≈ln(e4K/2)/2≈2K≫K, indicating that the lowtemperature sink is also stable. (c) The domains of attractions of the above sinks are separated by a third fixed point at

e2K∗=e4K∗+e−4K∗2⟹K∗≈0.305\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{2 K^{*}}=\frac{\mathrm{e}^{4 K^{*}}+\mathrm{e}^{-4 K^{*}}}{2} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad K^{*} \approx 0.305 \tag{6.69} \end{equation*}e2K∗=2e4K∗+e−4K∗​⟹K∗≈0.305​(6.69)​

which can be compared with the exact value of Kc≈0.441K_{c} \approx 0.441Kc​≈0.441. (2) Linearizing Eq. (6.68) near the fixed point gives

byt=∂K′∂K∣K∗=2tanh⁡4K∗≈1.6786⟹yt≈0.747\begin{equation*} b^{y_{t}}=\left.\frac{\partial K^{\prime}}{\partial K}\right|_{K^{*}}=2 \tanh 4 K^{*} \approx 1.6786 \quad \Longrightarrow \quad y_{t} \approx 0.747 \tag{6.70} \end{equation*}byt​=∂K∂K′​​K∗​=2tanh4K∗≈1.6786⟹yt​≈0.747​(6.70)​

compared to the exact value of yt=1y_{t}=1yt​=1. The bond moving procedure can be extended to higher dimensions. For a hypercubic lattice in ddd-dimensions, the bond moving step strengthens each bond by a factor of 2d−12^{d-1}2d−1. After decimation, the recursion relation is

K′=12ln⁡cosh⁡[2×2d−1K]\begin{equation*} K^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \cosh \left[2 \times 2^{d-1} K\right] \tag{6.71} \end{equation*}K′=21​lncosh[2×2d−1K]​(6.71)​

The high and low temperature sinks at K∗=0K^{*}=0K∗=0 and K∗→∞K^{*} \rightarrow \inftyK∗→∞ are stable since

K≪1⟹K′≈12ln⁡(1+22d−1K2)≈22(d−1)K2≪K\begin{equation*} K \ll 1 \quad \Longrightarrow \quad K^{\prime} \approx \frac{1}{2} \ln \left(1+2^{2 d-1} K^{2}\right) \approx 2^{2(d-1)} K^{2} \ll K \tag{6.72} \end{equation*}K≪1⟹K′≈21​ln(1+22d−1K2)≈22(d−1)K2≪K​(6.72)​

and

K≫1⟹K′≈12ln⁡e2dk2≈2d−1K≫K\begin{equation*} K \gg 1 \quad \Longrightarrow \quad K^{\prime} \approx \frac{1}{2} \ln \frac{\mathrm{e}^{2^{d} k}}{2} \approx 2^{d-1} K \gg K \tag{6.73} \end{equation*}K≫1⟹K′≈21​ln2e2dk​≈2d−1K≫K​(6.73)​

(Note that the above result correctly identifies the lower critical dimension of the Ising model, in that the low-temperature sink is stable only for d>1d>1d>1.) The intervening fixed point has an eigenvalue

2yt=∂K′∂K∣K∗=2d−1tanh⁡(2dK∗)\begin{equation*} 2^{y_{t}}=\left.\frac{\partial K^{\prime}}{\partial K}\right|_{K^{*}}=2^{d-1} \tanh \left(2^{d} K^{*}\right) \tag{6.74} \end{equation*}2yt​=∂K∂K′​​K∗​=2d−1tanh(2dK∗)​(6.74)​

The resulting values of K∗≈0.065K^{*} \approx 0.065K∗≈0.065 and yt≈0.934y_{t} \approx 0.934yt​≈0.934 for d=3d=3d=3 can be compared with the known values of Kc≈0.222K_{c} \approx 0.222Kc​≈0.222 and yt≈1.59y_{t} \approx 1.59yt​≈1.59 on a cubic lattice. Clearly the approximation gets worse at higher dimensions. (It fails to identify an upper critical dimension, and as d→∞,K∗→22(1−d)d \rightarrow \infty, K^{*} \rightarrow 2^{2(1-d)}d→∞,K∗→22(1−d) and yt→1y_{t} \rightarrow 1yt​→1.)

Fig. 6.10 The bond moving scheme for the Migdal-Kadanoff RG for b=2b=2b=2 in dimension d=2d=2d=2.

Fig. 6.11 The bond moving scheme for the Migdal-Kadanoff RG for b=2b=2b=2 in dimension d=3d=3d=3.

The Migdal-Kadanoff scheme can also be applied to more general spin systems. For a one-dimensional model described by the set of interactions {K}\{K\}{K}, the transfer matrix method in Eq. (6.44) allows construction of recursion relations from

Tb′({K′})=T({K})b.T_{b}^{\prime}\left(\left\{K^{\prime}\right\}\right)=T(\{K\})^{b} .Tb′​({K′})=T({K})b.

For a ddd-dimensional lattice, the bond moving step strengthens each bond by a factor of bd−1b^{d-1}bd−1, and the generalized Migdal-Kadanoff recursion relations are

Tb′({K′})=T({bd−1K})b.\begin{equation*} T_{b}^{\prime}\left(\left\{K^{\prime}\right\}\right)=T\left(\left\{b^{d-1} K\right\}\right)^{b} . \tag{6.75} \end{equation*}Tb′​({K′})=T({bd−1K})b.​(6.75)​

The above equations can be used as a quick way of estimating phase diagrams and exponents. The procedure is exact in d=1d=1d=1, and does progressively worse in higher dimensions. It thus complements mean-field (saddle point) approaches that are more reliable in higher dimensions. Unfortunately, it is not possible to develop a systematic scheme to improve upon its results. The RG procedure also allows evaluation of free energies, heat capacities, and other thermodynamic functions. One possible worry is that the approximations used to construct RG schemes may result in unphysical behavior, e.g. negative values of response functions CCC and χ\chiχ. In fact most of these recursion relations (e.g. Eq. 6.75) are exact on hierarchical (Berker) lattices. The realizability of such lattices ensures that there are no unphysical consequences of the recursion relations.

6.6 Monte Carlo simulations

Another advantage of discrete spins on a lattice is that they are easily amenable to numerical simulations. The rapid advances of computer processing power, and the advent of clever schemes have made numerical methods quite popular and attractive, to the extent that the study of simulations may be regarded as a field onto itself. As such, the description in this section is intended only as a brief introduction to the topic, and the interested reader should consult the many specialized books devoted to this subject.

Let us consider a system with many degrees of freedom, e.g. a set of N≫1N \gg 1N≫1 spins denoted by {s}, distributed according to the Boltzmann weights

P( s‾)=1Zexp⁡[−βH(s‾)]\begin{equation*} P(\underline{\mathrm{~s}})=\frac{1}{Z} \exp [-\beta \mathcal{H}(\underline{\mathrm{s}})] \tag{6.76} \end{equation*}P( s​)=Z1​exp[−βH(s​)]​(6.76)​

We are interested in calculating the expectation value of some quantity O\mathcal{O}O, which is in principle obtained as

⟨O⟩=tr⁡s‾[O( s‾)P(s‾‾)],\begin{equation*} \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle=\operatorname{tr}_{\underline{s}}[\mathcal{O}(\underline{\mathrm{~s}}) P(\underline{\underline{s}})], \tag{6.77} \end{equation*}⟨O⟩=trs​​[O( s​)P(s​​)],​(6.77)​

where tr⁡S‾\operatorname{tr}_{\underline{\mathbf{S}}}trS​​ indicates summing over all possible values of {s‾}\{\underline{\mathbf{s}}\}{s​}. Unfortunately, even for a discrete spin the number of terms in the sum is prohibitively large for interesting values of NNN, growing as qNq^{N}qN if each spin can be in one of qqq states. Monte Carlo procedures aim at evaluating the sum approximately by summing over a representative sample of configurations {s‾α}\left\{\underline{\mathrm{s}}_{\alpha}\right\}{s​α​}, as

⟨O⟩≈O‾=1M∑α=1MO( s‾α).\begin{equation*} \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle \approx \overline{\mathcal{O}}=\frac{1}{M} \sum_{\alpha=1}^{M} \mathcal{O}\left(\underline{\mathrm{~s}}_{\alpha}\right) . \tag{6.78} \end{equation*}⟨O⟩≈O=M1​α=1∑M​O( s​α​).​(6.78)​

The number of samples MMM is typically much smaller than the total number of states. The difficult part is to ensure that these MMM samples are chosen properly.

The question is now how to generate configurations that are weighted according to the distribution in Eq. (6.76). This is achieved by stochastically changing one configuration to another. Let us denote the microstates of the system by α=1,2,⋯ ,qN\alpha=1,2, \cdots, q^{N}α=1,2,⋯,qN, and indicate by Παβ\Pi_{\alpha \beta}Παβ​ the probability that the state α\alphaα is changed to state β\betaβ in the next time step. Note that while it is helpful to maintain the mental image of the system evolving in time, the stochastic dynamic rules are an artificial set of steps for generating the desired configurations. Since Παβ\Pi_{\alpha \beta}Παβ​ are transition probabilities, they are constrained by

Παα=1−∑β≠αΠαβ.\begin{equation*} \Pi_{\alpha \alpha}=1-\sum_{\beta \neq \alpha} \Pi_{\alpha \beta} . \tag{6.79} \end{equation*}Παα​=1−β=α∑​Παβ​.​(6.79)​

The above transition rules are an example of a Markov process, in which the state of a system depends on the preceding step(s). Let us assume that initially (at time t=0t=0t=0 ) the probability to select a state α\alphaα is Pα(0)P_{\alpha}(0)Pα​(0), e.g. Pα(0)=1/qNP_{\alpha}(0)=1 / q^{N}Pα​(0)=1/qN if all states are equally likely. These probabilities change at the next step of the Markov chain (t=1)(t=1)(t=1), and are now given by

Pα(1)=∑β=1qNPβ(0)Πβα.\begin{equation*} P_{\alpha}(1)=\sum_{\beta=1}^{q^{N}} P_{\beta}(0) \Pi_{\beta \alpha} . \tag{6.80} \end{equation*}Pα​(1)=β=1∑qN​Pβ​(0)Πβα​.​(6.80)​

In terms of the vector of probabilities P⃗\vec{P}P and the transition matrix Π\PiΠ this is just

P⃗(1)=P⃗(0)⋅Π.\begin{equation*} \vec{P}(1)=\vec{P}(0) \cdot \Pi . \tag{6.81} \end{equation*}P(1)=P(0)⋅Π.​(6.81)​

Similarly, after ttt steps, we have

P⃗(t)=P⃗(0)⋅Πt.\begin{equation*} \vec{P}(t)=\vec{P}(0) \cdot \Pi^{t} . \tag{6.82} \end{equation*}P(t)=P(0)⋅Πt.​(6.82)​

After many steps of the stochastic dynamics, the probabilities converge to steady-state values P⃗∗\vec{P}^{*}P∗ which form a left eigenvector of the matrix Π,1\Pi,{ }^{1}Π,1 since

P⃗(t)=P⃗(0)⋅Πt≈P⃗∗⇔P⃗∗=P⃗∗⋅Π.\begin{equation*} \vec{P}(t)=\vec{P}(0) \cdot \Pi^{t} \approx \vec{P}^{*} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \vec{P}^{*}=\vec{P}^{*} \cdot \Pi . \tag{6.83} \end{equation*}P(t)=P(0)⋅Πt≈P∗⇔P∗=P∗⋅Π.​(6.83)​

Having established that irrespective of the initial choice, the Markov probabilities converge to a unique set, how can we choose the transition rates to insure that the final probabilities are the Boltzmann weights in Eq. (6.76)? The change in the probability of state α\alphaα in one step is given by

Pα(t+1)−Pα(t)=∑β≠α[Pβ(t)Πβα−Pα(t)Παβ].\begin{equation*} P_{\alpha}(t+1)-P_{\alpha}(t)=\sum_{\beta \neq \alpha}\left[P_{\beta}(t) \Pi_{\beta \alpha}-P_{\alpha}(t) \Pi_{\alpha \beta}\right] . \tag{6.84} \end{equation*}Pα​(t+1)−Pα​(t)=β=α∑​[Pβ​(t)Πβα​−Pα​(t)Παβ​].​(6.84)​

For the pair of states α\alphaα and β\betaβ, the first term in the square brackets is the increase in probability due to transitions from β\betaβ to α\alphaα, the second is the decrease due to transitions in the opposite direction. The probabilities are thus unchanged if these "probability currents" are equal for every pair, i.e.

PαΠαβ=PβΠβα.\begin{equation*} P_{\alpha} \Pi_{\alpha \beta}=P_{\beta} \Pi_{\beta \alpha} . \tag{6.85} \end{equation*}Pα​Παβ​=Pβ​Πβα​.​(6.85)​

This is known as the condition of detailed balance, which in the case of Boltzmann weights implies

ΠαβΠβα=PβPα=exp⁡[−β(Eβ−Eα)].\begin{equation*} \frac{\Pi_{\alpha \beta}}{\Pi_{\beta \alpha}}=\frac{P_{\beta}}{P_{\alpha}}=\exp \left[-\beta\left(E_{\beta}-E_{\alpha}\right)\right] . \tag{6.86} \end{equation*}Πβα​Παβ​​=Pα​Pβ​​=exp[−β(Eβ​−Eα​)].​(6.86)​

Note that since ∑βΠαβ=1\sum_{\beta} \Pi_{\alpha \beta}=1∑β​Παβ​=1, summing Eq. (6.85) over β\betaβ gives

(P⃗⋅Π)α=∑βPβΠβα=Pα∑βΠαβ=Pα\begin{equation*} (\vec{P} \cdot \Pi)_{\alpha}=\sum_{\beta} P_{\beta} \Pi_{\beta \alpha}=P_{\alpha} \sum_{\beta} \Pi_{\alpha \beta}=P_{\alpha} \tag{6.87} \end{equation*}(P⋅Π)α​=β∑​Pβ​Πβα​=Pα​β∑​Παβ​=Pα​​(6.87)​

as expected, the detailed balance condition ensures that P⃗\vec{P}P is the left eigenvector of the transition matrix, corresponding to its steady state.

A popular method for implementing the detailed balance condition is the Metropolis algorithm: Let us attempt a transition from state α\alphaα to state β\betaβ. This transition is always accepted if it lowers the energy, and with a probability exp⁡[−β(Eβ−Eα)]<1\exp \left[-\beta\left(E_{\beta}-E_{\alpha}\right)\right]<1exp[−β(Eβ​−Eα​)]<1 if it increases the energy, i.e.

Παβ=qαβ{1 for Eα>Eβexp⁡[−β(Eβ−Eα)]<1 for Eα<Eβ.(6.88)\Pi_{\alpha \beta}=q_{\alpha \beta} \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } E_{\alpha}>E_{\beta} \tag{6.88}\\ \exp \left[-\beta\left(E_{\beta}-E_{\alpha}\right)\right]<1 & \text { for } E_{\alpha}<E_{\beta} .\end{cases}Παβ​=qαβ​{1exp[−β(Eβ​−Eα​)]<1​ for Eα​>Eβ​ for Eα​<Eβ​.​(6.88)

[^6]In the limit of zero temperature only moves that reduce the energy are accepted and the system proceeds towards a local energy minimum. At finite temperature moves that increase the energy are sometimes accepted. The factor of qαβq_{\alpha \beta}qαβ​ is the frequency with which the move from α\alphaα to β\betaβ is attempted. Since the energy change has the opposite sign for the transition in the reverse direction (from β\betaβ to α\alphaα ) the acceptance criteria are reversed. If qαβ=qβαq_{\alpha \beta}=q_{\beta \alpha}qαβ​=qβα​, it is easy to see that Eq. (6.86) is satisfied irrespective of the energy change.

As a concrete example, let us consider simulating a system of NNN Ising spins, in which at each step we attempt to flip (σi→−σi)\left(\sigma_{i} \rightarrow-\sigma_{i}\right)(σi​→−σi​) a randomly chosen spin. (In this case, the attempt frequency is qαβ=1/Nq_{\alpha \beta}=1 / Nqαβ​=1/N for states related by a single spin flip.) This change is accepted if the resulting energy change ΔE\Delta EΔE is negative, and otherwise accepted with probability exp⁡(−βΔE)\exp (-\beta \Delta E)exp(−βΔE). For Ising models with short-range interactions calculating ΔE\Delta EΔE is very fast, since we only need to consider the bonds emanating from the flipped spin. We can start from a randomly generated initial state, and apply the stochastic (Monte Carlo) rule many times. The average of the quantity O\mathcal{O}O is then estimated as

⟨O⟩≈O‾=1T∑t=τT+τO[σ(t)].\begin{equation*} \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle \approx \overline{\mathcal{O}}=\frac{1}{T} \sum_{t=\tau}^{T+\tau} \mathcal{O}[\sigma(t)] . \tag{6.89} \end{equation*}⟨O⟩≈O=T1​t=τ∑T+τ​O[σ(t)].​(6.89)​

The first few steps are strongly influenced by the initial condition and must be discarded. The equilibration time τ\tauτ is not known a priori, and will be discussed further in chapter 9 . Typically it grows as some power of the correlation length, and thus as a polynomial in NNN at the critical point. The relaxation time τ\tauτ also determines the accuracy of the estimate in Eq. (6.89): States separated by a few time steps are highly correlated, and thus the number of independent configurations appearing in the above sum is of the order of T/τT / \tauT/τ. The relaxation time also depends on the set of attempted moves for transitions, and there are schemes for accelerating equilibration by clever choices of moves. There is also an interesting way to employ Monte Carlo simulations for a position space renormalization group calculation which will not be discussed here.
